website_summaries.verdict: An excellent all-around camera microphone with plenty of professional touches, including a silicone shock mount.
pros: An all-metal body protects against drops and signal interference, and the included silicone shock mount reduces vibration pickups while looking professional
Two windscreens included for variable weather conditions
Two output cables for smartphone and camera connectivity
cons: Audio balancing issues have been reported when using with older iPhones

customer_reviews.title: Just doesn't work
customer_reviews.text: I tested this with my iPhone X. I had to buy the adapter cable, which was fine. I used it with the native iPhone video app and with a different video recording app. I even tried using the cable meant for cameras (not phone) just in case. I could discern no difference in either the amplification/pickup quality of my voice nor reduction in ambient noise. If I listened really carefully maybe there was very slightly less echo? But certainly not enough to make it worth the money. I returned it and am back on the hunt.
customer_reviews.author: BellaBull

customer_reviews.title: Seems solid, sounds decent.
customer_reviews.text: Very small, working well for me for interviews - I'm using it with the Comica mixer/amplifier. It does need to be amplified. If they made an amplified version of this mic I would try it. The amplified Comica mic I got is all light weight plastic and seem flimsy. This mic has a metal body and seems pretty solid. Sound quality is not much different than the plastic mic though. Decent, not great. Usable though. So for not much $$ you can get a pretty big step up over the built in camera mic.
customer_reviews.author: George Marinich

customer_reviews.title: Good for the money
customer_reviews.text: Well, it's a $50 mic so be realistic with expectations. It works great for the Nikon d3200 and our smart phones (Samsung, Galaxy, iPhone). I was bummed it didn't work on my Canon XF100 but I can live with that. I watched a review that made it sound really great. I wasn't so impressed with the Samsung. Has a bit of white noise I thought, but if you have a gain control I bet you could get some crisp sound. I'm not disappointed because like I said, it was around $50 which IMO is a cheap mic so it's worth the purchase.
customer_reviews.author: Brian Auer

customer_reviews.title: Great build quality and great sound especially with very light editing
customer_reviews.text: Very comparable to the Rode video Micro, for $10 less then the Rode you get the capability to plug this into your smartphone. Overall the included case, 2 windscreens, cold shoe shock mount, different cables for different devices such as your smartphone and the great sound, although a bit treble strong which can easily be fixed with editing, will amaze you at the price point although i did feel it was too close to the Rode price and could be dropped just a little more, I will say though the $50 is not unreasonable for the build quality of the mic as well.
customer_reviews.author: ReadySetGameTop Contributor: Photography

customer_reviews.title: Great Shotgun mic and quality accessories
customer_reviews.text: This is a great mic for the price and I think very hard to beat. The shock mount is good quality in comparison to others in the price range. I don’t see it braking as easy and that was my primary reason for purchasing the comica. I have no complaints with the mic. The one noticeable thing that might be a complaint to others is the mic isn’t going to be great for distance but it’s not designed to be used that way. Goes great with the canon g7x iii
customer_reviews.author: Mjhiggs16

customer_reviews.title: Fabulous microphone Better than the Rode VideoMicro
customer_reviews.text: I'm really impressed with this microphone. The build quality is fantastic, right on par with the Rode VideoMicro. It also comes in a very nice protective carrying case, and I love the fact that it includes a TRRS and a standard 3.5mm audio cable so you can use the mic with your camera/recording device AND your smartphone right out of the box. I also compared the sound against that of the Rode VideoMicro and almost couldn't tell the difference. To me, they sound so close in quality that the Comica becomes the clear winner just based on the additional value as compared to the Rode. Disclosure: Comica did provide me with a free microphone.
customer_reviews.author: spyros

customer_reviews.title: Not bad.
customer_reviews.text: Not bad for the price. This has been a great microphone for quick video when needed. The red paint peels off the plastic and flakes all over. The frame that holds the mic make me a little nervous quality wise so I haven't removed the mic from the frame. It is a tight fit and assume if it is going to brake it will do so while either taking the mic off or putting it on the frame. Comes with a great case. Love that it doesn't need batteries. Sound is not bad at all.
customer_reviews.author: wood

customer_reviews.title: Distorted sound
customer_reviews.text: Several of my footage became unusable due to distorted sound from this mic. I went to the lowest possible in the audio gain and still the sounds were distorted. I tried it on my DSLR , mirrorless and camcorder and it is the same thing. I bought a Sony microphone and it works fine with all of my cameras. Also the wind muff is of very poor quality, it is extremely large and gets in the shot for it's size and the hairs tend to come off and make a mess all over. I should have returned it when I had the chance.
customer_reviews.author: Doc fmch

customer_reviews.title: Pretty decent camera microphone for the money.
customer_reviews.text: I purchased the CVM-VM10II a couple of months ago and I have used it a few times shooting videos on my Lumix G7 and I am pleased with the overall sound quality and construction. It is definitely better than the built in mic on the camera and it does a pretty decent job of picking up what I want to record and not the surrounding ambient noises. Are there better mics out there? Sure, but at a cost. If your looking for an external mic that's has decent sound quality that won't break the bank, this little guy will get the job done.
customer_reviews.author: Burton Nuse

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for vlogging among other things
customer_reviews.text: The Comica CVM-VM10 II MICRO Compact Condenser Shotgun Video Microphone is identical to the first version of this mic, except that this mic has a newly designed stand (shock mount). It's a solid shotgun mic and a an alternative to the Rode VideoMicro. Perfect for vlogging among other things. It's compact and lightweight and the build quality is very nice too. Best bang for your buck in my opinion, you get a windscreen, windmuff, 3.5 mm jack cable for camera and one for smartphones plus a very nice case. I personally like the stand on this one better than the VM10.
customer_reviews.author: Marlon

customer_reviews.title: It's OK but Rode VideoMicro is better
customer_reviews.text: I tested this against the Rode VideoMicro and it's just not as clear, although I like the way this mount looks over the Rode. The wind screen does not work AT ALL; the 'dead cat' wind muff does work but doesn't look like the first photo – the hair is unnecessarily long and it just looks like a cat's tail ) I'd suggest pay the extra $10 to get the legit Rode mic instead of this copy product:

If you are new to making videos don't hesitate get this external microphone.

customer_reviews.title: Impressive turn out

It kills most of the background noise, which makes the post work a lot easier. This shotgun video microphone works great on my canon 5D iv. It is really compact and light weight, which allows me to shoot in variety angels without any trouble. The package is real nice. It comes with a bunch of accessories, such as a shock absorbing mount, the wind muff, and the pop filter. I love it.

customer_reviews.author: JeffNJ

customer_reviews.author: Sarina
